entry.title: Review Booklet (Template) In Margin Analysis For Company Profitability Reporting
entry.content:
What Can the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) App Do For You?

The booklet provides Management Accounting insights, which are not yet available on a structured and aggregated level.

It allows a multi-dimensional analysis of contribution margins on 3 levels using Margin Analysis relevant attributes.

 The booklet technology offers highly adaptable financial reporting based on actual postings (ACODCA). This ensures that users have access to precise and detailed information, enhancing decision-making processes.

With advanced formatting options, users can customize reports to suit their needs. The technology also supports downloading and collaboration features, making it easier for teams to work together seamlessly.

As technology advances, so does the booklet. It incorporates AI features, ensuring that users benefit from the latest innovations in financial reporting.

The booklet has standard extensibility functionality to enable adoptability via key user apps.

Contribution Margin Measure Structure And The Reason It Is Called A Template

SAP uses the Functional Areas from Best Practice Content, so the selection needs to be adjusted by customers.

That is why it is called a Template.

If you use the SAP delivered Function Areas (YB18 to YB50) in your cost objects, you can use the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) app out of the box.

If not, you need to adjust the selection in the CDS Analytical Query using Key User tools.

I will explain this in another blog.

 

Key Capabilities

The new review booklet is delivered with SAP Cloud ERP 2508.

It is based on SAP Best Practices Contribution Margin Financial Statement Version (FSV) YPS2 and its semantic tags.

It shows 3 levels of Contribution Margin:
I           Revenues / Related variable costs
II          / Related fixed costs, warranties and variances
III         / Company periodic costs

The booklet is cross-industry, so it can read different account assignments:

  • Market Segments (EO) for Sales Order etc.
  • Projects (PR), with all attributes
  • Service Contracts/Orders (SC, SV), with all attributes
  • Cost Centers (KS, KL) and Orders (OR) for non-allocated costs

With Universal Journal integration we can read costs directly from those cost objects including the attributed Margin Analysis dimensions. There is no need to settle or allocate costs to Market Segments.

 

Figure 1: Year-to-date comparison of 3-level contribution margin for a company code

The hierarchical structure of the measures is hard coded in the underlying CDS Analytical Query.

Each measure has semantic tags assigned from FSV YPS2, so GL Account assignments can be adjusted in configuration. You can use your own FSV, but you must use the same semantic tags.

Fixed/variable costs are read from the ACDOCA amount fields.

 you also need to select additional ACDOCA dimensions for the following measures to get correct amounts:

  • Functional Area (to distinguish between COGS and periodic costs)
  • Billable Control (remove warranty costs)
  • Subledger Line Item Type (to distinguish production variances)

Figure 2: Hierarchical measure structure for the 3-level contribution margin

Data Selection In Detail

The system reads actual revenue and cost in Company Code currency from ACDOCA using the cube I_GLAcctLineItemSemTagGLAcct with Semantic Tags.

 You can access all Margin Analysis data from a set of Cost Objects. Select the Account Assignment Type as follows:

  • EO (Market Segment)
  • PR (Project)
  • SV (Service Order Item)
  • SC (Service Contract)
  • OR (Order)
  • KS (Cost Center)
  • VB (Sales Document Item)
  • KL (Cost Center and Activity)

You need to distinguish the measures between Read (RKF) and Calculated (Calc) figures.

Calculated figures are based on Read Key Figures and just have a calculation formula without selection criteria.

The Read Key Figures always use a Semantic Tag in the selection.

Please refer to the full list, to get an overview.

Figure 3: List of calculated and read key figures with selection criteria

The reason why additional selection on some figures is required is because SAP uses the Semantic Tag PL_RESULT on several RKFs. PL_RESULT contains all G/L Accounts maintained in the financial statement version.

To ensure we do not count costs on the same account in several key figures, we need to restrict further.

 

Periodic Costs

Let’s have a look at the periodic costs first. We want to distinguish periodic costs into the following:

  • Marketing
  • Sales
  • Administration
  • Research & Development

There are 4 different measures using the Semantic Tag PL_RESULT.

We added the delivered Best Practices FSV YPS2 some more Primary Cost G/L Accounts with SAP Cloud ERP 2508 under a new node called Common Operational Cost Gls (Node ID 74). Please check if you need additional G/L Accounts and add them. If you were a customer before SAP Cloud ERP 2508, you will need to add this node and all G/L Accounts you want to see costs under PL_RESULT.

 The PL_RESULT tag is used here (all costs) to ensure we also see costs in the report that are not being allocated to Margin Analysis using Universal Allocation or Settlement. Primary costs remain on Cost Centers or WBS Element. We could restrict via a Semantic Tag to the corresponding allocation or settlement G/L accounts, if settlement and allocation were done from all object using the secondary G/L Accounts, but this is rarely the case.

 To ensure we have different costs summed on the 4 measures, we use the Functional Areas from Best Practices:

  • YB35: Marketing
  • YB30: Sales
  • YB40: Administration
  • YB50: Research & Development

The Functional Area is always filled in ACDOCA and derived from the Cost Object (Cost Center, WBS Element) on which the periodic costs are posted.

Of course, we continue to display periodic costs allocated or settled to Market Segments. Users can then also drill down into the used dimensions like Product or Customer Group. The system credits allocated costs to the cost center without the Market Segment dimension. This ensures that costs do not appear twice in the total.

 

Figure 4: Example for allocated and non-allocated periodic costs by G/L account in the review booklet

 

Price Differences (Or Production Variances)

A similar case is Price Difference or Production Variance, which can occur on Production Orders and are posted to Market Segment dimensions of a Production Order, once it is completed.

We want to distinguish variance into the following:

  • Input Price
  • Input Quantity
  • Resource Usage
  • Lot Size
  • Output Price
  • Input Remaining

So, we have different Read Key Figures all with Semantic Tag PL_RESULT, since different variance can occur on the same G/L Account.

Therefore, we use the Sub-ledger Line Item Type to further restrict the different amounts.

It is filled by production variance calculation in ACDOCA when posted to Market Segments.

 

Warranty Costs

We also want to show warranty costs as a measure using Semantic Tag PL_RESULT, since all kinds of G/L Account can carry warranty cost.

For all warranty costs, the Billable Control (or Accounting Indicator ACDOCA-BEMOT) is filled to configurable values like “Non-Billable Demand” or “Goodwill”. This allows us to read with Billable Control not initial.

All Other Costs Of Good Sold

For all other COGS measures in our structure, we make use of the fix and variable separation in ACDOCA and have different sematic tags.

In addition, we use the Best Practice Functional Areas

  • YB18: Cost of Goods Sold
  • YB25: Consulting/Services

To ensure we only count product and service-related costs in the Contribution Margin I and II we also restrict to Billable Control/Accounting Indicator is initial to not include warranty costs.

 

Revenues And Sales Deductions

For revenue and sales deduction figures, it is enough to read the semantic tags and assigned G/L Accounts without the Functional Area.

 

Navigation to Line-Item Reporting

To verify the aggregated data, users can navigate to the line-item report for Margin Analysis. They can then filter using the criteria for each measure. Semantic tags are resolved into G/L Account through navigation.

Other filters are kept as defined.

Figure 5: Navigation to Display Line Items – Margin Analysis to measure warranty costs

 

Figure 6: Filters in Display Line Items – Margin Analysis to measure warranty costs

The sum in the line-item report should fit the figure in the booklet, with the following limitations:

  • For Fixed/Variable Cost measures, you can verify only the Fixed Amount and need to calculate the Variable as Total minus Fixed.  This is available only for Group Currency.
  • If the booklet includes additional page filters for fields which are not available as filters in the line-item report (e.g. for fiscal quarter), the sum might not match.

Conclusion And Outlook

You now understand the purpose and logic of the booklet and know when you need to adopt.

We would highly appreciate your feedback on this article.

In future we plan to add additional features to the booklet, e.g.

  • Display of amounts in Group Currency
  • Selection and comparison of several Company Codes
  • Commenting
  • Business Insights powered by AI

More Information on SAP Cloud ERP:

  • Finance Collection Blog (roadmap, quarterly release highlights, microlearnings) here
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Customer Community for Finance here
  • What’s New here
  • Help Portal Product Page here
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition release info here
  • SAP S/4HANA PSCC Digital Enablement Wheel here
  • Early Release Webinar Series here
  • Inside SAP S/4HANA Podcast here
  • Best practices for SAP S/4HANA Cloud here
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Community: here

entry.title: Forgot to Punch Again! - How to Limit Attendance Regularization in SuccessFactors Time Tracking
entry.content:
Generally people forget to punch, due to which many issues arise - frequent regularizations, compliance pain, and payroll reconciliation nightmare!

That's where our SuccessFactors Time Tracking solution comes in. Today, I'm going to show you a simple, and efficient way to restrict the number of attendance regularizations an employee submits, say, only 2 per month.

The Business Scenario:

In most organizations, employees have the option to apply regularizations when they forget to clock in/out. But there should be a limit.

Problem Statement:

Employees are filing unlimited attendance regularizations. Management wants to limit 2 regularizations per month per employee.

Step-by-Step Configuration:

Step 1: Create a Time Type – Attendance Regularization

  • Time Type Name: Attendance Regularization
  • Classification: Attendance

Step 2: Assign the Time Type to Time Profile

  • Navigate to Time Profile configuration.
  • Add Attendance Regularization under Available Time Types

Step 3: Setup Time Valuations

🔹Time Valuation 1: Count Attendance Regularizations

  • Valuation Type: Compare Threshold with Input Groups and Count Events
  • Input Time Type Group:
    • Time Type = Attendance Regularization
    • Time Category = Working Time
  • Time Category: Counted Events
  • Period: Monthly

This valuation counts the number of times an employee files an Attendance Regularization during a month. The output is placed in a Time Type Group Above Attendance Regularization Day Count.

Time Valuation-

Input Time Type Group-

Time Type Group Above-

🔹Time Valuation 2: Apply the 2-Time Limit and Raise Error

  • Valuation Type: Aggregate Input Groups and Split
  • Input Time Type Group: Attendance Regularization Day Count (from the previous valuation)
  • Threshold Value: 2
  • Message Flag Field: Raise Message on Time Type Group Above

This valuation verifies if the employee has crossed the 2-regularization limit for a month. If they try to apply more than 2, the system will give an error message.

Time Valuation-

Time Type Group Above-

Step 4: Assign the Time Valuations to Time Recording Profile

Assign these two new Time Valuations to the employee's Time Recording Profile.

  • Go to Time Recording Profile configuration.
  • Under Time Valuations, add above valuations, which we set up.

Testing the Solution: Proving the Limit Works

It's time to test it. We have two situations:

  • Employee should not able to apply attendance regularizations more than 2 times within the same month, and

  • The counter will reset at the beginning of the month, and regularizations are possible again.

Scenario 1: Employee Tries to Submit three Regularization in the Same Month

Test Steps:

  • Employee submits the 1st attendance regularization.

  • Employee submits the 2nd attendance regularization.

  • Employee tries to apply 3rd regularization in the same calendar month. System shows an error message to avoid it.

Scenario 2: Employee apply regularization in next month

Test Steps:

  1. Month is changed (e.g., from July to August), the system resets the attendance regularization count.

  2. Employee submits an attendance regularization in the new month.
  3. System accepts the submission (count starts fresh).

Conclusion:

You can apply a monthly cap on attendance regularizations in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking.

Let’s Hear From You!

Did you do something like that? Let’s talk in the comments below!

entry.title: Re: Output preview button is disabled in manage purchase...
entry.content:
The Output Preview button in the Fiori app may be disabled due to one or more of the following:

  • Missing Output Determination Configuration in OPD (Output Parameter Determination)
  • No output item generated for the PO in the app
  • Incorrect form template assignment or missing communication channel
  • PO not released or approved, depending on your output trigger settings
  • Output status not set to “Ready”, which is required for preview

Even if OPD is configured, the Fiori app requires additional setup to generate and preview the PDF inline.

What you can do is

  • check the output determination and ensure that Output type is correctly configured for the PO document type, Form template is assigned, Channel is set to Email or Print, Conditions are met (e.g., PO is approved)
  • verify Output Items in the Manage Purchase Order app, go to Output Management section, Check if any output item is listed, if not, the preview button will remain disabled.

Also by clicking “Output Details” takes you to ME9F, which still works because it uses the classic NAST output framework. This confirms that the issue is specific to the Fiori Output Management setup.

Check this blog by @Toseef_Ahmed_An  which might be helpful to you

entry.title: Re: Delivery weight not being pulled through from Sales o...
entry.content:
Some of the possible reasons as to why the weight is not fetched into delivery are

  • in copy control VTLA, for your item category, ensure routine 101 is set against the field "Item Data". This routine ensures that fields like net weight (NTGEW) and gross weight (BRGEW) are transferred from the sales order item (VBAP) to the delivery item (LIPS).
  • If delivery is packed, weights may be recalculated based on handling units. Check if packing logic overrides item-level weights.
  • Custom logic in delivery creation (e.g., USEREXIT_MOVE_FIELD_TO_LIPS) may interfere. Review exits in program MV50AFZ1.

entry.title: Re: Saving the Edited Fields of Data Table to backend
entry.content:
Looking at your executeAction call, it looks like your override isn't specifying the properties at the correct level. You need a second properties reference in the overrides since the actual properties are within a properties object in the action.

changedObjects.forEach(obj => {
    context.executeAction({
        "Name": "/ABC/Actions/Update.action",
        "Properties": {
            "Properties": obj
        }
    });
});

entry.title: BEHAVIOR_ILLEGAL_STATEMENT dump | Technical workarounds
entry.content:
If you're working with SAP RAP, you've probably encountered the infamous BEHAVIOR_ILLEGAL_STATEMENT dump.

This dump could occur when the following statements are made in a RAP context:

  1. Explicit use of COMMIT WORK or ROLLBACK WORK statements - the transaction handling and database commit is exclusively handled by RAP
  1. Calling update or enqueue functions that bypass RAP's controlled transaction flow
  2. Direct database modifications outside of RAP's managed approach.

 

Understanding the Core Challenge

The core challenge lies in RAP’s approach to transaction management. The RAP transactional model is built on the concept of Logical Unit of Work (LUW), which ensures data consistency and integrity by treating all operations within a transaction as a single, indivisible unit. It includes a late-save phase followed by a cleanup. RAP follows a controlled Logical Unit of Work (LUW) pattern with two distinct phases:

  • Interaction Phase: Data modifications are stored in a transactional buffer
  • Save Sequence: Data is validated and persisted to the database

On the other hand, a COMMIT WORK statement that immediately persist changes to the database. When these two approaches collide, you get runtime errors that can halt your application.


Available Solution or Workaround

Our goal is to call our explicit commit or any other ‘Illegal statement’ in a different task. There are four ways to do that:

 

  • BGPF (Background Processing Framework)

SAP Documentation - : Background Processing Framework | SAP Help Portal

 

  • Parallel Processing

Implementation Examples :- ABAP Cloud - Parallel processing , Two Different types of Parallel Processing example... - SAP Community

 

 

  • Application Jobs for background Processing

Implementation Examples :- Example Implementation Using Interfaces IF_APJ_DT_EXEC_OBJECT and IF_APJ_RT_EXEC_OBJECT | SAP Help Portal ,

Introducing Application Jobs

 

  • RFC Workaround (On-Premise Only)

We can create a wrapper RFC FM with our logic and call that using DESTINATION 'NONE' statement. Which will be called in a different task.

Note : This workaround are not supported by Cloud Environments.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Private Cloud – Best-Practice for “Fixed Inpu...
entry.content:
Yes, SAP S/4HANA supports this via Process Manufacturing (PP-PI) using:

  • Master Recipes instead of routings
  • Co-products and by-products in the BOM
  • Negative quantities to represent by-products
  • Yield recording during confirmation to capture actual output mix

This setup allows you to fix input quantities while capturing variable outputs per batch.

Now you have to setup Master Data Model by using Master Recipe with Phases for chemical reactions. In the BOM,

  • Input materials: fixed quantities,
  • Output materials:
  • Main product: planned yield
  • Co-products: flagged with “Co-product” indicator
  • By-products: entered with negative quantity

In Material master, for co-products: enable Joint Production in MRP 2 view. For by-products: set valuation type and costing relevance appropriately.

With the above settings, the process would be

  • Planned Order created for main product
  • Production Order generated with BOM and recipe
  • During confirmation:
  • Enter actual yield quantities for each output
  • System adjusts consumption and cost allocation

Goods receipt posts actual quantities for all outputs

SAP supports batch-specific valuation if grades differ in value.

Finally, for Cost Allocation methods,

  • use Apportionment Structure in costing view of material master
  • Define equivalence numbers to split costs across co-products
  • For by-products:
  • Use net realizable value method
  • Reduce cost of main product accordingly

Co-products are settled separately; by-products reduce primary product cost.

In nutshell, the summary is

Also go through this blog by @sergey_nozhenko

entry.title: Re: Asset APC value in AR02 report double
entry.content:
The discrepancy you're seeing between AR02, AR03, and AW01N for asset number 3200000014—where AR02 shows double the value compared to AR03 and AW01N—likely stems from how the asset was posted in the current fiscal year and how reporting logic differs across transactions.

Please find below the chart for your understanding

Likely root causes

  • The asset was capitalized in the current fiscal year (01.04.2025).
  • It may have been posted twice in different depreciation areas (e.g., area 01 for book depreciation and area 10 for tax).
  • AR02 aggregates values across all depreciation areas, so it shows double the APC (₹2,100,000).
  • AR03 and AW01N show values per depreciation area, hence they show ₹1,050,000 (which is correct for one area).

This behavior is normal for assets posted in the current year, especially if parallel valuation is active.

Please check the below areas

  • Asset Master (AS03) - Review depreciation areas and acquisition values per area.
  • Transaction History (AW01N) - Check posted values and depreciation per area.
  • Configuration - Confirm if parallel valuation is active (e.g., for IFRS vs. local GAAP). Check if fiscal year variants differ across ledgers.

entry.title: Re: 在创建应付汇票时，需要进行存应付汇票保证金，如汇票金额10000.00元，需要存汇票保证金3000.00元...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Can you please check whether the following information resolves your issue (GenAI was used to help generate this content)?

When creating a payable draft in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you can link a margin to the draft by following these steps:

  1. Create the Payable Draft: Use the ‘Create BoE Payable - China’ Creating Electronic BoE Payable app to initiate the creation of a bill of exchange payable. Ensure that you input the transaction data correctly.

  2. Link the Margin: During the creation process, you can specify the margin amount that needs to be deposited. This is typically done by entering the margin amount in the relevant field when setting up the draft.

  3. View Margin and Draft Status: Once the draft is created, you can view the margin amount and the status of the draft in the ‘BoE Payable for Cashier’ tile. This tile allows you to manage and monitor the status of your drafts, including any associated margins.

  4. Monitor Status: Use the ‘Monitor Status of Bank Communication - China’ app to track the status of the electronic bill of exchange and ensure that the margin is correctly linked and acknowledged by the bank.

Creating Electronic BoE Payable

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: "Parking Lot" for approval of Sales Order Workflows
entry.content:
We have implemented flexible workflow for sales documents in On premise S4HANA and its working well.

We have a requirement to “park” approvals for certain sales documents. There are sales documents which are created and immediately blocked for further processing (using the standard workflow process).

The customer will request delivery of the sales order at a later stage which could be weeks after it was created. We would like a process by which the orders the customer has requested for delivery are submitted for approval i.e. they are sent to the inbox of the approver.

Currently the order is immediately sent to the approver and sits in the inbox of the approver until an email is sent to approve the order which sort of defeats the purpose of automation. It also raises the risk of orders being approved in error and just clogging the inbox of the approver with orders which are not yet relevant for approval.

I just wanted to get the thoughts of others of how this process can be implemented.

entry.title: SAP TechEd 2025: Building Trust on SAP BTP
entry.content:
After a few virtual SAP TechEd years, we’re excited to be back at an on-site event in Europe! And in Berlin, no less, a city just as vibrant as this year’s TechEd promises to be. If you plan to attend SAP TechEd this year, we have once again curated a selection of security-related content for you. Here’s a preview of the 2025 sessions!

Navigating security and compliance in SAP BTP

In this SAP BTP subtrack, we’ll be focusing on security, compliance, and identity & access management.

Start out with our strategy talk: Building trust on SAP BTP: Strategy meets security (ST105). We’ll explore core principles for building resilient, regulation-compliant applications using more-secure-by-design development practices and integrated platform tools.

Next up is our Road map for security and compliance services in SAP BTP (XP802), where we will show you upcoming features and enhancements that boost protection, help ensure regulatory alignment, and support more-secure, scalable cloud architectures.

If you’d like to explore more-secure application development on SAP BTP, join our deep dive session Fortifying SAP BTP: Best practices for more-secure software development (XP200) as well as our hands-on workshop Developing more-secure applications on SAP BTP: A practical approach (XP260). Learn key practices such as threat modeling, security assessments, and more-secure coding. You’ll work directly in SAP BTP and gain practical skills to embed security into your development process.

Identity and access management is your thing? Check out our SAP Cloud Identity Services in a nutshell (XP201). This deep dive will help you understand our strategy, core concepts, and best practices for identity lifecycle management to help secure and streamline access across SAP software landscapes. In the related hands-on workshop, Identity lifecycle management with SAP BTP and Microsoft Entra (XP261), we’ll show you how to integrate SAP Cloud Identity Services with Microsoft Entra to deliver unified user lifecycle management across SAP software and third-party applications. Another Deep Dive session, Mastering zero trust: SAP Customer Identity and Access Management (XP207) lets you explore the security features in our SAP Customer Identity and Access Management solution so you can build more secure, scalable, and privacy-compliant digital experiences.

Cloud applications: Security and compliance

Security is not just of vital importance for our platform, SAP BTP, but also a key quality of our cloud applications – most importantly SAP Business Suite. The Cloud Application – Security and Compliance track explores SAP’s holistic approach, detailing how our security frameworks and compliance certifications help organizations protect data and mitigate risk. It’ll allow you to dive into SAP Business Suite, examining how its components support businesses in safeguarding their critical assets.

  • Strategy Talk Build it, run it, live it: Our security and compliance strategy (ST114)
  • Roadmap From control to confidence: What’s ahead for security and compliance at SAP (CA815)
  • Deep Dive Insider threats: Security based on AI, analytics, and IAM (CA100)
  • Deep Dive Lock in security and unlock compliance with SAP Business Suite (CA103)
  • Deep Dive Security monitoring and response with tools for securing applications (CA104)
  • Hands-on Workshop Hands-on experience with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection, cloud edition (CA163)

As you browse the session catalog and build your own agenda, please keep in mind that new sessions, schedules and registration features will be added throughout the weeks leading up to the event. Check back from time to time to see what’s new. And remember to register for hands-on sessions early, as they have limited capacity and tend to fill up quickly!

Can’t come to Berlin? Tune in to SAP TechEd Virtual!

If you can’t make it to Berlin, we’ve still got you covered. SAP TechEd Virtual is a free online event that’ll help you broaden your technical expertise and explore SAP’s latest innovations. For example, you can catch our virtual SAP BTP Security roadmap session: XP802v | Road map for security and compliance services in SAP BTP

Join the SAP Security and the SAP TechEd Communities to stay up to date – and sign up for the monthly SAP Security Newsletter to get all the latest news delivered directly into your inbox!

entry.title: Re: How to mass-extend existing customers and vendors (BP...
entry.content:
Below would be the approaches you can check

1. Mass-Extend Customers/Vendors to Additional Company Codes

Use the Migration Object: Extend Existing Business Partner with New Org Levels via the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit.

Scope Item: 1RK – Data Migration Using Staging Tables
You can extend BPs to new company codes (e.g., create new KNB1 or LFB1 records).
Template available in the Migration Cockpit for staging table upload.

Check this SAP Help - Migration Object for extending BPs 

2. Mass-Extend Customers to Additional Sales Areas

This is more limited in Public Cloud:

  • The Migration Cockpit does not support extending to new sales areas if one already exists.
  • Workaround: Use Mass Maintenance App to insert new records into KNVV (Customer Sales Data).

- Export existing data
- Use action code “I” to insert new sales area records
- Upload via Start Mass Maintenance – Business Partners

3. Mass-Extend Vendors to Additional Purchasing Organizations

Yes, this is supported via:

Migration Object: Extend Existing Supplier with Additional Org Data
You can extend vendors to new purchasing orgs (LFM1 records)
Use the Migration Cockpit with staging tables

4. Convert Customers to Vendors (or Vice Versa) Under Same BP Number

This is not supported directly in mass via standard apps.

  • You can manually assign new roles (e.g., FLVN00 for vendor, FLCU00 for customer) in the BP app.
  • For mass conversion:

- Use Mass Maintenance App to add new roles
- Or use Migration Cockpit with “Extend Existing BP” object

Important: You must ensure that the BP is role-compatible and that mandatory fields are filled for each role.

Summary of tools:

entry.title: SONDA Gallery is SAP Certified for SAP BTP with Generative AI Capabilities
entry.content:
Artificial intelligence is rapidly transforming enterprise software, bringing smarter automation, contextual insights, and enhanced user experiences to business-critical systems. In tax and accounting, where precision and compliance are essential, AI is helping organizations to manage complex data with greater agility and confidence. Solutions that integrate generative AI with robust platforms like SAP are setting new standards for usability and performance—offering not just automation, but intelligent assistance tailored to the needs of modern finance teams.

SONDA, a technology partner with headquarters in Chile and strong presence in Brazil, has been a driving force in digital transformation across the Americas. With expertise in tax management, foreign trade and outsourcing, SONDA delivers solutions to help companies navigate regulatory complexity and operational challenges through a portfolio of SAP-based solutions, automation and process integration.

Among these, SONDA Gallery stands out as a tax-accounting solution for Brazil. Originally co-innovated with SAP in 2016 and built natively on SAP HANA, Sonda Gallery is designed to support Brazilian tax legislation with high performance and real-time data analysis. Evolving the solution across the time to adopt SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) and integrated with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (SAP DRC), the solution now features generative AI capabilities, including a virtual assistant trained on product documentation. This assistant helps users navigate the system, summarize notes, translate content, and identify key deliverables—bringing a new level of intelligence to their tax management solution.

Sonda has been a long time SAP partner and has always valued the importance of offering quality-proven solutions to the market, regularly certifying its solutions with SAP Integration and Certification Center (SAP ICC) support. Since 2020 Sonda Gallery has been following SAP strategy toward taxes for Brazil and being SAP Certified, initially through an SAP Tax Declaration Framework for Brazil (SAP TDF) scenario, and later through an SAP DRC for Brazil scenario. With the new Built with SAP BTP Utilizing Generative AI Hub Capabilities (BTP-EXT-GenAI) certification scenario Sonda identified an opportunity to reposition and offer customers with a solution tested against SAP Global AI Ethics Policy requirements.

However, the certification criteria did not initially account for Sonda Gallery’s ABAP-based authentication model, which relied on SAP Logon Tickets and ABAP objects. Rather than delay the process, SONDA responded with remarkable speed and precision. In just two weeks, the company re-engineered Sonda Gallery’s authentication to fully adopt SAP Cloud Identity, a modern and secure mechanism native to SAP BTP platform. This migration not only met the certification requirements but also enhanced the solution’s flexibility, allowing integration with identity providers like SAP S/4HANA Cloud and Microsoft Entra ID.

Completing the certification on time was a testament to SONDA’s technical agility and deep understanding of SAP architecture. It also reinforced the company’s commitment to delivering future-ready solutions that meet the highest standards of security, usability, and compliance, tested through SAP Certification. With this achievement, SONDA Gallery is now officially SAP Certified for SAP BTP with generative AI capabilities—positioning it as a Reliable, Responsible and Relevant tax-accounting solution for Brazil.

Name: Harish Vatsa

Harish, tell us about yourself.

I am Harish Vatsa, a Senior Architect and SAP CX Practice Leader at Bosch Middle East. With over a decade of experience in the software industry, I have worked across delivery, pre-sales, and consulting roles. My core belief lies in the power of technology to solve real-world problems, and I find immense joy in helping customers unlock business value through SAP solutions.

Outside of work, I’m an enthusiastic community builder, lifelong learner, and a proud father of two amazing children. I enjoy mentoring young talent, visiting customer sites to understand their challenges firsthand, and translating those needs into scalable SAP solutions. Building strong human connections, fostering innovation, and continuously evolving, these are values that drive me both personally and professionally.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

My primary area of expertise lies in SAP Customer Experience (CX), with a focus on SAP Commerce Cloud, Sales and Service Cloud, and end-to-end digital transformation. I also actively contribute to architecture consulting, customer journey mapping, and capability development within the Middle East SAP ecosystem.

A usual day for me is a dynamic mix - I might start by reviewing a digital transformation roadmap for a regional retail client, move into a pre-sales pitch to a potential customer, conduct a knowledge-sharing session with junior consultants, and end the day collaborating with global teams on SAP best practices. I frequently engage in customer workshops, SAP events, and hands-on product innovation discussions, all of which fuel my passion for technology and community leadership.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?

The SAP Community has been a cornerstone in my professional growth — a place where I’ve learned, shared, and connected with some of the most brilliant minds in the industry. Being an SAP Champion is not just a title for me; it's a way to give back to the very ecosystem that shaped my journey.

My inspiration stemmed from my desire to empower others. I’ve always believed that shared knowledge has a ripple effect. What sets SAP Community apart is the diversity of thought, and I always walk away with new ideas, solutions, or perspectives. It’s my professional think tank.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

Treat the SAP Community not just as a knowledge base, but as your professional ecosystem.

Start by actively participating - ask questions, write blogs, comment on others’ posts, and join groups or events aligned to your interests. Consistency matters more than intensity. Don’t worry about being perfect - your shared experiences can help someone else avoid a costly mistake or discover a better way.

Also, connect with people, not just content. Some of the best learning I’ve experienced has come from one-on-one conversations with other SAP enthusiasts who were generous with their time and insights.

entry.title: Logging of Payload using exception subprocess when the receiver IDOC channel is in error
entry.content:
Hello All,

As part of logging of payload when an error occurs in the IDOC receiver channel level, Implemented a groovy script within the exception subprocess to capture the payload. 

This is the script used to capture the payload - 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
def Message processData(Message message)
{
def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;
def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
def Filename = message.getHeader('Filename_SI_KR15', String);
  message.setHeader("FileName",Filename); 
  def mimeType = Filename?.toLowerCase()?.endsWith(".xml") ? "application/xml" : "text/plain";
if(messageLog != null)
{
messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("${Filename}", body, "${mimeType}");
}
return message;
}

The specific script is used in this format because according to the filename, if it is .txt file then it goes into a sftp server or if it is .xml goes to the IDOC channel, so hence if it is .txt then the mimetype will be text/plain or else it will be application/xml. 

 

So here when the error is occurring at the IDOC channel level, the payload is not getting captured into the monitoring. But if it is for TXT file, it gets captured successfully. While putting into trace mode also we checked but it goes to the exception subprocess without any payload. 

Why does this happen? Is it due to some IDOC channel configuration? Why only for IDOC channel the payload is not getting logged? Is there any way to capture the payload and log it in monitoring when IDOC channel is going into error?

Thanks,

Radhika D S

entry.title: Re: IDOC/ALE best practise to Build IDOC_DATA(EDIDD) in ABAP
entry.content:
KISS principle.

1) No need to build a Deep Structure

2) No need to create a function module

3) Yes, build the table of EDIDD lines containing all segments, and call the released function module MASTER_IDOC_DISTRIBUTE (the only one to be documented in the SAP Library).

Example with one custom segment type.

DATA ls_ze1xxxx TYPE ze1xxxx.
DATA ls_edidd TYPE edidd.
DATA lt_edidd TYPE TABLE OF edidd.
DATA ls_edidc TYPE edidc.

CLEAR ls_ze1xxxx.
ls_ze1xxxx-field_1 = '...'.
ls_ze1xxxx-field_2 = '...'.

ls_edidd-segnam = 'ZE1XXXXX'.
ls_edidd-sdata = ls_ze1xxxx.
APPEND ls_edidd TO lt_edidd.

CALL FUNCTION 'MASTER_IDOC_DISTRIBUTE'
  EXPORTING
    master_idoc_control = ls_edidc
  TABLES
    master_idoc_data    = lt_edidd
  EXCEPTIONS
    " list of all exceptions
    OTHERS              = 5.

 Development of a Function Module for ALE Outbound Processing | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to implement workflow in FB60 or FV60...
entry.content:
Key findings from the post are

  • FB60 (Create Incoming Invoices) is not workflow-enabled in Public Cloud.
  • FV60 only supports parked invoices with PO reference, not standalone FI invoices.
  • The Fiori app "Create Supplier Invoice" is workflow-enabled, but it may generate temporary document numbers and is designed for MM scenarios.
  • SAP recommends using blocked invoice workflows or custom logic for non-MM invoice approvals.

Some workaround options are

Use Payment Block Strategy

  • Configure automatic payment blocks on invoices posted via FB60.
  • Trigger workflow based on the block status using custom logic or workflow for blocked invoices.
  • Use My Inbox for approval and release.

Custom Workflow via BAdI or Extension

  • Implement a custom workflow scenario using BAdI BADI_FDC_POST or BADI_FDC_WORKFLOW.
  • Capture invoice creation via FB60 and route it through a custom approval process.
  • Requires development effort and may need SAP support in Public Cloud.

Check these documentations

blog by @mickaelquesnot 

SAP Help documentation

entry.title: Re: End-to-end Testing using Peppol Exchange in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition
entry.content:
Dear Jini,

I assume you have sent the invoice to yourself. If your Customer Invoice is stuck in "Received by Sender Access Point", and you have not received any incoming Supplier invoice, and the Peppol Monitor shows the error above, then this seems to be related to the BTP Destination setup and the SSL certificate for the Communication User (Inbound Connections).

The solution involves ensuring proper communication between SAP DRC and S/4 HANA Cloud by setting up the correct authentication method and certificates. A typical problem identified is related to the use of BasicAuthentication in the BTP Destination, which is not supported with SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud Backends. The recommended approach is to use ClientCertificateAuthentication with a private certificate in PFX format.

Communication Directions and Certificates

  1. S/4 HANA Cloud to SAP DRC: Uses the private certificate of S/4 HANA for sending invoices or credit notes. The public certificate of S/4 HANA is used by SAP DRC via service binding.
  2. SAP DRC to S/4 HANA Cloud: Utilizes the private certificate of the BTP Destination to authenticate. S/4 HANA Cloud allows authentication via the public certificate of the BTP Destination. This direction is used to receive various responses and validation results.

Please verify that your Communication User's Inbound Communication Authentication matches the public certificate from the BTP Destination, as outlined in Adding Details to the Communication User | SAP Help Portal.

Regards,

Uwe

entry.title: Re: Error while deploying CDS based services on on premis...
entry.content:
Hello,

I have found a solution to this deployment issue:

  • In a standard CAP application, cds is often started directly using cds run or cds-serve in start script of package.json.
  • In XSA environments, the platform does not start the app via cds-serve and it doesn´t start with node server.js directly, but instead loads the module as a factory.
  • Hence, a file server.js which exports cds.server as factory is required and the start script can execute server.js file. 
  • E.g. my server.js file:
console.log('Server.js initialized');
// srv/server.js
const cds = require('@sap/cds')

cds.on('bootstrap', app => {
  app.get('/health', (_req,res) => res.status(200).send('OK'))     // 200
  app.get('/', (_req,res) => res.status(200).send('OK'))           // optional: 200 für Root
})

if (require.main === module) cds.server()
else module.exports = cds.server

cds.once('listening', ({ server }) =>
  console.log('CAP listening on', server.address().port)
)
 
and in my package.json my start script is "node server.js".
 
Doing so, 
  • XSA can control the application startup process.
  • Using require.main === module provides the advantage of enabling local development independently of the deployment setup.
  • During deployment, the Node.js buildpack in XSA defines the application startup process.

And my mta.yaml snippet for service module looks like this:

name: cap-srv
    type: nodejs
    path: .
    parameters:
      buildpack: sap_nodejs_buildpack
      memory: 512M
      instances: 1
      # Health-Check robust: checks the port 
      health-check-type: http
      health-check-timeout: 180
      health-check-http-endpoint: /health
 
In addition, I had to bind hdi container, db module, xsuaa/xssec und xsenv into my mta.yaml as modules so that the app was deployable and consistent. 
Note: The health check is a simple fix that if there's no 200 OK response, it may appear as if the app is in a "staging/unstable" state, even though the process is running. A simple fix is to implement a small health endpoint and configure the health check to use that instead. 
 
Best regards
Rufat

entry.title: Crystal Report - design question since can't have subreport within subreport
entry.content:
Hello, may I have help solving this problem?

The top level entity we are reporting on is a customer System.  Systems can have Sites and Sites can  have Access Contacts.  I am working with a report developed previously by a coworker and at that time we didn't have the best database design.  The Sites record had 4 slots for contact information.  So our subreport structure was as below.

System Data II was the main report.  Most of this report comes from our system data record.  Then we have another table of sites and a query xrySystemToSites which gets all the sites for that system.  The subreport SiteSub is in the Report Footer of System Data II.  Site Sub was created with the report wizard so it doesn't exist as its own rpt file.

Today, we no longer have 4 hardcoded access contacts.  We have another table where each site can have 0 to n contacts.  So I am replacing the AccessContacts area on the top right with...well, I don't know what I am replacing it with because I haven't gotten anything to work.

If I save SiteSub to an external rpt and then work with it as the top level report, it correctly pulls in the next subreport I wrote to get all contacts for a given site, but as we all know once I try to link Report->SubReport->SubReport, it will not work.

So my design problem is 1:many (systems to sites) then another 1:many (sites to contacts).  I want a section with the heading Sites, present site #1's data with its variable number of contacts , site #2 with its data and contacts, etc.  Thank you for any help!

entry.title: Re: Can the Forward Automation Settings be turned off or...
entry.content:
Hello @Noni 

In a three-system DTP environment, you can prevent changes made in the Test (T) system from being transported to Production (P) by adjusting STMS transport routes to eliminate the T → P path or setting them to manual. Additionally, restrict import permissions in Production to only allow approved transports. Removing start days in the scheduling screen won’t be effective if the system needs at least one; instead, disable or delete the automation.

Let me know if you need further assistance

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Fiscal year variant V3 is not defined for calendar ye...
entry.content:
This typically occurs when:

  • an asset master record has an incorrect or defaulted capitalization date or activation date set to 01.01.1900.
  • Fiscal year variant V3 (April–March) is not defined for calendar year 1900 because it's not a valid business year.

Below are the recommended fix

  • Check Asset Master Data via AS03 for asset 40000003-0 in CoCd 1810. Review the capitalization date, activation date, and depreciation start date. If any of these are set to 01.01.1900, update them to a valid date (e.g., 01.04.2023).
  • Validate Fiscal Year variant settings via OB29 to confirm that V3 is defined for all relevant calendar years (from 2006 onward). You do not need to define it for 1900, as that year should never be used.
  • Check Asset Transaction history via AW01N to view asset values and transaction history. Look for any legacy data or migration entries that might have defaulted to 1900.
  • Finally, If the asset was migrated incorrectly, consider recreating the asset with correct dates using AS91 (Legacy Asset Transfer) with proper values and dates

entry.title: Re: "Parking Lot" for approval of Sales Order W...
entry.content:
While SAP Flexible Workflow doesn’t natively support “parking” sales orders like FI documents, you can design a gated approval trigger using one of the following approaches:

Option 1: Use a Custom Status or Field to Trigger Workflow

  • Add a custom field (e.g., “Ready for Approval”) to the sales order header.
  • Initially set this field to blank or ‘No’ when the order is created.
  • Only when the customer requests delivery, set the field to ‘Yes’.
  • Configure the Flexible Workflow start condition to trigger only when this field = ‘Yes’.

Benefits:

  • Approvers only receive relevant orders.
  • Orders remain blocked until explicitly marked for approval.


Option 2: Use a Custom Workflow Scenario with Delayed Trigger

  • Create a custom workflow scenario that listens for a specific change event (e.g., delivery date update or status change).
  • Trigger the workflow only when the order is updated to reflect readiness for delivery.

Technical Notes:

Use BAdI SD_SALES_DOCUMENT_WORKFLOW to define custom start conditions.
You may also use event linkage via SWEC to trigger workflow on change.


Option 3: Use a “Parking Lot” Table or App

Create a custom Fiori app or table where sales orders are “parked” until the business user marks them as ready. Once marked, the app triggers the workflow using API or event.

entry.title: Re: Upgrade of SAP S4H Public Cloud - Manage My Views
entry.content:
Hello @JAS3311 

There is no automated way to transfer personal views from the deprecated Manage Journal Entries app (F0717) to the new Manage Journal Entries app (F0717A) in S4HANA Public cloud.

You must manually rebuild the views in F0717A, as S4 Public Cloud does not support migration between different app IDs.

3591778 - F0717A Manage Journal Entries - New Version: Additional Authorisation Checks

Adapting SAP Fiori UIs at Runtime - Key User Adaptation

With rergards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Best practices for splitting software collections wit...
entry.content:
Hello @TAKUMIKURASHIMO 

You can’t partially release a software collection; all objects in it must be released together in the S4 HANA Public cloud

Below are SAP Best practices

  • Group objects with direct technical dependencies in the same collection.
  • Split unrelated features or workstreams into separate collections to allow independent releases.
  • Keep business roles/catalogues in their own collection.
  • Use Where-Used analysis to check for hidden dependencies before splitting.

This ensures dependency safety while giving you more flexible release cycles.

Check below SAP Reference documentations

  • SAP Help Portal – Managing Software Collections
  • SAP Help Portal – Where-Used Analysis for Extensibility Objects

With kind regards

Chuma
